newsitem.title: DUBAI: Saudi Arabia cracks down on haj overstayers.
newsitem.headline: Saudi Arabia cracks down on haj overstayers.

text.p: Saudi Arabia is cracking down on thousands of foreign women for overstaying in the kingdom after the end of the annual Moslem haj pilgrimage to Mecca and Medina last month, a Saudi newspaper said on Friday.

Arab News said a special task force had approved measures to force such people to leave, including cutting water and electricity to buildings housing them since a deadline for their departure took effect on Thursday.

Deportation centre sources said about 13,000 overstayers, from the period between the Moslem fasting month of Ramadan in February and the end of the haj in late April, were being deported every day through Jeddah, a Red Sea city close to the holy Moslem sites.

Thousands of pilgrims, mainly from Pakistan, India, Bangladesh and Egypt, are known to take advantage of their presence in Saudi Arabia and stay beyond their haj visa to seek work in violation of the kingdom's strict immigration laws.
Saudi authorities say such violators pose a security threat and have organised campaigns to arrest and deport them.
